div.p: My parents, my mum’s always been an accountant, my dad’s, it’s a strange thing, my dad’s always been working with people with disabilities;
he did go off and do other things, he did strangely enough, he was a security guard for a little bit but that wasn’t what he wanted to do;
he knew what to expect with cerebral palsy like it’s down one side, the balance/coordination thing so yeah he knew what I could do
and what I could possibly do because during the ‘80s they didn’t know much about people with cerebral palsy, they were always thrown away
or treated as "special", yeah, so he knew what to look for. When I was born with cerebral palsy the doctors used to give me pills
and basically I was a vegetable in a wheelchair, when I came off the meds I couldn’t feed myself, couldn’t clothe myself,
couldn’t even talk so my dad always taught me to walk, talk, that sort of thing. Yeah and when I got older my brother took me out in my wheelchair
my family has been very supportive, yeah, we’ve experienced a lot of things together, yeah.
With my disability they always push me to do sit-down jobs but again I am quite stubborn and quite headstrong I always want to do
something different and always do something different and challenge myself and when I said “I’m bored with retail work”, even though I did enjoy it,
“I want to be a security guard or try to be a security guard”, my dad was like “you can’t do that, you’ll be on your feet all day”
or something like... But I’m not so yeah but my mum would say “if you want to do it, do it” so and “if you fall down at least you know”
you know if you go for something and it falls down flat well at least you’re going for it because you sit there and you go I can’t do that
so and life slips you by but yeah...
